Authors:
Akihiko Tsuneda, Marie Louise Davey, Ichiko Tsuneda,
Randolph S. Currah
Title:
Endophoma, a new didymellaceous endoconidial genus from
bat-cave soil
Keywords:
coelomycetes, cleistopycnidia, endoconidia, Phoma,
Pleosporales, troglodytic fungi, Didymellaceae
Abstract:
A new endoconidial taxon, Endophoma elongata gen. et sp.
nov., isolated from bat-cave soil, is reported from Alberta, Canada. It
is morphologically unique in producing two forms of unilocular,
endoconidial conidiomata, i.e., a superficially Phoma-like spherical,
often ostiolate form and a cylindrical, non-ostiolate, often setose
cleistopycnidial form. Locules of both forms are pseudoparenchymatous,
filled with hyaline, thin-walled, endoconidial conidiogenous cells.
Endoconidia are hyaline and unicellular. One- or two-celled
chlamydospores are abundant in culture. Phylogenetic analysis of the
LSU, ITS, and Î²-tubulin regions indicates Endophoma is a member of the
Didymellaceae and remote from all other endoconidial genera.
Endoconidiogenesis has not been previously reported within the
Didymellaceae, and Endophoma represents the first report of a
coelomycetous, endoconidial genus in the Pleosporales.
